Thinking about Lean collab:

  1. It would be very useful to have chat spaces that are subject-specific and the unicity of that subject be proven in Lean
  • if the concepts are synonyms: a Lean proof of that should be given as well
  1. a chat space about each unique Math or philosophic concept should exist as well as common chat spaces (between concepts) Maybe a semantic graph? Maybe a n-dimensional \R space (like a vector space for AI embeddings)?

How hard would it be to have the conversations Lean-indexed (under the control of this concept-managing lean lib)? If you know about other ppl thinking about this: please link.

Thank you for your time. I'm new here and I did not see this idea explored with the intent of making collaboration more efficient and Lean-clean.

That does not mean this lib will replace Zulip: but that we could have access to the relevant chats from inside Lean. For example, this convo has URL: #general > ZulipChat is good. But is it good enough for Lean?
and it could be indexed with some concepts that will make it available when those types are used in any Lean project

I'm hearing a specific proposal from you - can you articulate why you like this? In other words, what is the issue you are trying to solve? Put differently: why would such spaces be useful to you? What, do you hope, will change by them existing?

I was involved in a discussion about my new lib on physical measures in Lean and somebody had to point me to 2-3 different discussions about this concept. It would be useful:

  1. to not need a guide to get to those chats
  2. to almost guarantee that you can read all the relevant chats (on the Lean concepts of interest)

1. the chat links would be available in the Lean editor
  2. if we model the semantic space as vector space: it could be made embeddable in any AI so the answers can contain links to chats and the libs that use those types/concepts
I don't expect that people will care to manually supply the required meta information. I think that a better approach is to get a better search in Zulip logs.

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

I don't expect that people will care to manually supply the required meta information. I think that a better approach is to get a better search in Zulip logs.

how about AI summarization that will provide the meta info?
I think that you're looking for an (AI-powered) semantic search.

I think that the existing AI systems should be able to provide sematic search in user data, though I don't know how to make it work and how much would it cost (you don't want to put all Zulip logs in a ChatGPT/Gemini header).

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

I think that you're looking for an (AI-powered) semantic search.

no. that is already possible albeit it becomes usable only when the AI weights include the new content (so there is a painful lag).

I was proposing a search that is Lean-controlled not by third parties. It is true that meta-info is painful to set so I proposed having a special prompt (standardized by the community) to use any AI engine to compose the meta.

I believe that the collaboration should be the other way around: the AI engines should take the prepared vector space from this new Lean library so they can have a very precise search (without hallucinations) in the Lean domain.

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

information

This could be a much simpler-to-implement approach. But could that search be controlled by Lean types (inside the IDE?)
Are you asking for a loogle-like search for Zulip?

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

I don't expect that people will care to manually supply the required meta information. I think that a better approach is to get a better search in Zulip logs.

This could be a much simpler-to-implement approach. But could that search be controlled by Lean types (inside the IDE?)

Eric Wieser said:

Are you asking for a loogle-like search for Zulip?

About Loogle: it lacks semantic links so we can browse it with concepts. Am I the only beginner to feel the need?

Eric Wieser said:

Zulip

So if Loogle would have a semantic web and be available from inside Lean IDE and index the Zulip chats as well: that would cover my present need
Many Zulip chats are about notions that aren't yet in the library. How do you expect an automated system to link them to Lean expressions?

Yury G. Kudryashov said:

Many Zulip chats are about notions that aren't yet in the library. How do you expect an automated system to link them to Lean expressions?

I expect the linking to happen after the formalization. So they become useful to people who will begin to use the formalization.
(or improve the formalization)
In other words: any Lean lib could have an interactive documentation represented by those chats about it.
If there are too many scattered Zulip threads about formalizing some concept or theory in Lean, I think someone should create a document summarizing the key points of those threads.

Bulhwi Cha said:

If there are too many scattered Zulip threads about formalizing some concept or theory in Lean, I think someone should create a document summarizing the key points of those threads.

Great idea. Someone or some thing: like an AI
I would just like Google to index the Lean Zulip. It’s really frustrating that it doesn’t seem to and I don’t know why.

Jason Rute said:

I would just like Google to index the Lean Zulip. It’s really frustrating that it doesn’t seem to and I don’t know why.

I could be because of the "#" character in the URL:

https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/ZulipChat.20is.20good.2E.20But.20is.20it.20good.20enough.20for.20Lean.3F

Our Zulip is large, and fast-moving, but I don't think it's yet at the point where highly-involved members of the community don't know what's going on across most domains. So, human-powered search is probably fine for now.

i do understand that it is annoying that as a non-highly-involved (or new) member you have to rely upon the highly-involved members to know what's going on. the fact that finding the information you're looking for is less-than straightforward, can give a feeling of being gate-kept...

Edward van de Meent said:

i do understand that it is annoying that as a non-highly-involved (or new) member you have to rely upon the highly-involved members to know what's going on. the fact that evidently finding the information you're looking for is less-than straightforward can give a feeling of being gate-kept...

It is that too, but mainly I do not want to bother people and I was thinking that Lean can prepare for AI too. We know that now AI is already doing wonders using Lean.
https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/ai-solves-imo-problems-at-silver-medal-level/
(How do we prepare to position Lean as a common language between humans and AI? It may have the best chance because it is very descriptive of complex concepts)
(could Lean become the most exact prompt language?)
But Zulip is for human-to-human discussion? There are plenty of people working on AI with Lean. Do you know about #Machine Learning for Theorem Proving ?

Jireh Loreaux said:

But Zulip is for human-to-human discussion? There are plenty of people working on AI with Lean. Do you know about #Machine Learning for Theorem Proving ?

no, but I will be there too. I only say that we can be welcoming of humans as well as AIs in the Lean community. If possible to do both with the same solution.

But: if the general consensus is that my ideas about conceptual search are not useful... I accept the consensus.
Christian Tzurcanu has marked this topic as resolved.

@Christian Tzurcanu I guess I'm just not quite sure of what you want the AI to do on Zulip. Here are some things I could see an AI being useful for related to Zulip:

  1. Summarizing threads (this should already be possible just by pasting the full thread into an off-the-shelf LLM, although I've never actually tried to copy an entire thread, so it may not be as easy as I imagine).
  2. Find relevant threads (again, you could just use an LLM, but you'd need to train on the Zulip corpus and update it periodically, since the context window wouldn't be large enugh). At the same time, Zulip just recently tried to improve their search feature, and I'm regularly capable of finding threads that I vaguely remember from years ago, so probably just improved search suffices here.

My point about human-to-human discussion is that this is exactly the kind of thing at which LLMs excel (because Zulip contains mostly natural language). In contrast, there's not as much Lean code, so trying to search (even semantically) while incorporating Lean code seems not that useful to me. Am I missing your point here?

I am just a beginner here. I will try to adapt if most people consider the present state of communication is good enough.

I guess I feel like the point of Zulip is primarily for natural language communication. Maybe if you gave some explicit examples of how you imagine this working then people would have a better understanding of your ideas.
For example, I don't understand how any of the present discussion could/should be "driven from the Lean IDE" or "include much more Lean and much less natural lang".

sure. I can describe this in practical terms:

I am in the IDE and I hover over the imports.

import Mathlib.Algebra.MonoidAlgebra.Basic

Now I see nothing there while tips appear all over the other text. I could see: a tip with a pointer to the Mathlib docs and another pointer to the chat that is about that particular lib.

Other examples:

  • a certain library wants to define some chats in its comments.
  • another lib links to mathematical concepts like those in Mathematics Subject Classification 2020 in its metadata (prob also in comments)

Also the reverse:

  • a mapping from the MSC2020 to the extant Lean libs

I could think of more, but.. nobody thought useful anything I wrote up to this point..
